In addition, there is a room dedicated to people who came as a prisoners of war here, and finally settled here with their families for forever to give new identity or society to A&N Islands. 

Anthropological museum is located on Middle Point, it was closest sightseeing to our hotel, blue sea, and so we walked up to the place. It is quite close to Hotel Shompen. Other important places near to museum are Ananda, & Annapurna restaurants which are quite popular eating joints in the area. You can simply walk to these restaurants, from the Museum, to have delicious lunch. 

The Museum remains open from morning 9AM till evening 5PM. However ticket counter and souvenir shop remains open till 4PM only. Museum remains closed on Monday and Government Holidays. Currently, as of Mar 29 2017, ticket costs INR 40/- only. 

If you are history enthusiastic, you are going to take 3.5-4 hours to cover the complete museum, however it would surely take 2 hours of your time even at normal pace. The place can be skipped only if history does not entice you and knowing tribal world attracts you. A&N islands is just a best place to swim in the ocean. 

Please note that you cannot use any camera, any camera and mobile phone camera, within the museum. You would need to hand over your camera at reception. However you can carry your mobile phone, but you must not use it to take the photographs. More

title: Know our history - past and present
review_text:
The anthropological museum is centrally located in Port Blair with a well planned layout. Parking is adjacent to the building and you walk in next door. No photography is allowed inside the museum. You begin from the ground floor and walk your way across three floors. 
The museum tells the history of the original aboriginal inhabitants of these islands - Andamanese, Jarawa, Onge, Sentinelese, Nicobarese, Shompen. While the tribes are of Mongoloid or African descent, anthropologists are still researching how such differing origins came together on these islands. The Sentinelese have managed to resist contact from the mainstream population, while few others like the Jarawas are now being left alone to protect them from extinction. The Nicobarese have been absorbed into the mainstream after being converted to Christianity by early British settlers, and some are in government jobs. 
The layouts authentically represent the tools, shelters and living styles of these tribes. There also details of the current population composition on the islands and how people from eastern and southern parts of India have settled here. All in all a very interesting hour giving you a peek into the interesting history of our islands. More

title: Could have been so much more interesting (sigh)
review_text: I resisted visiting this museum -- I'm a cultural anthropologist myself, and I know the quality of Indian museums (sadly enough as I'm Indian myself). Put those facts together, and I had a sense this place would be a disappointment. But when we found ourselves with an hour to kill on Port Blair, we thought -- why not? If you know nothing about the Andamans' native inhabitants, then you'll learn a bit about them -- tools, technologies, food, dwellings etc. But the place showcases them in a way we're told they may never have wanted to be showcased. It's a pretty conventional exhibit that doesn't tell us much about how they currently live (other than saying many keep to themselves entirely -- really? is that even possible?) or really anything very interesting (folklore? religion? belief systems? or even how tourists go see them anyway under the pretense of visiting the volcanic mud pots etc.). If you've an hour to kill, go--and since most folks don't bother thinking beyond the touristy things to do, perhaps they should. But you may be better off contemplating human existence and our ethical obligations toward tribal and other indigenous communities while watching the sun go down at Chidiya Tapu. More

It is maintained by the Anthropological Survey of India. The museum illustrates the tribal life and culture of the four Negrito Tribes of the Andamans viz. the Jarawas, Sentinelese, Great Andamanese and the Onges and two Mongoloid tribes of the Nicobar viz. the Nicobarese and the Shompens. Museum 
has exhibit the things that are collected from the tribal, like their weapons, utensils, hut, boat etc. Their life is also shown by pictures and photograph. There is shop for buy stuff. 

It' is situated at the Phoenix Bay that's best accessed via the Phoenix Bay jetty. It can reach from the jetty from the Foreshore Road, either by hailing a cab or driving down the road from the city centre. 
Ph. +91-03192-232291. 

Entry Fee-10 per person for Indians, 20 per still camera 
Visiting Timings -All days of the week except Monday & Govt. Holidays. 
8.30 AM to 1.00 PM, 1.30 PM to 4.30 PM. More

title: Typical Government Establishment- but well concieved
review_text:
A visit to this place is a must for those who are interested in understanding the Tribal Social fabric of Andamans.The Museum covers the Social, Economic,and Historical aspects of the lives of the Jarawas,Onge, Sentinelese Tribes of Andamns and the Shompens,Nicobarese tribes of Nicobars. The dwelling units models are available. Weaponry used by them are displayed. Their hunting techniques are illustrated. But the sad part all this is that tourists are not allowed access to see and experience the tribal life style.In that sense this museum is only place you can gain understanding of life-style of thses tribes. 
Like all government establishments it is little bit dimly lighted and somewhat shabby. Rule enforcers rule the place,carrying out surprise checks on those who take photographs without paying fees. 
On the whole very educative place. More

title: Andaman and Nicobar Life- a glimpse
review_text:
The Anthropological Museum is well-organized and the facts about the different tribes of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands are very well- documented. 
The pictures are interesting. We get an insight into the lives of these foraging communities. 
The made to scale dwellings are realistic, we see the tools and instruments they use. 
An excellent source of information and a must-see. 
The Museum Gift Shop has shells, shell craft and wood craft. 
The ticket is a wothwhile memento to be preserved of an Onge tribesman!

title: Museum depicting Glimpse of Tribal life-Yesterday and Today
review_text:
I visited this museum after returning from the cellular jail. This is a centrally located place near Andman and Nicobar Tourist office. It has clean and green ambiance with aesthetically decorated frontal wall. Stepping provides it an extra grace. One should see the things in its own local context and not compare with national and international museum galleries. In that way it is a well maintained small museum. With its limited resourses it serves its purpose well. 
It provides us a glimpse of tribal life of those old days and present day living pattern and behavior of Jarwa tribal’s. There is good display of, photographs posters, models .artifacts, tools and weapons used by them. I was particularly fascinated by the replica and models of boats, canoes and huts, depicting their way of hunting, living and eating. There is small souvenir and gift shop, just before the entrance of the museum gallery. 
We enjoyed and passed about one hour in this museum and came out, thinking, their carefree way of living with minimum requirements. In contrast modern well developed civilized man with all his collections of materiel and costly gadgets seems heavily care-laden. If you come to visit this far off place and interested in knowing the life pattern of original inhabitants of these islands, it is worth visiting this museum. 
Satish Tripathi ,Gorakhpur,India More

title: The building looks nice from out, inside nothing to hold your attention
review_text:
I've heard that the Prince of Wales museum in Mumbai has some modern styled exhibits, but having not seen it personally, i have to say that the Anthro museum falls in the category of all Indian museums - pathetic due to lack of any vision by the Anthropological Survey of India. 

The exhibits are ancient and covered with dust. There is no timeline or way of figuring out what is the current state of the various tribes mentioned. Whoever thinks this is a good museum obviously hasn't seen any normal museum in a developed country. 

There are clear signs not to touch things but you'll find some morons who insist on getting into the replica huts to get photos taken of themselves. See photo attached as evidence. 

If you have time to kill and really really want to see how some of the original inhabitants lived, then you can consider breezing through in 15 minutes. 

Its a shame that not only have we destroyed most of the tribals and their culture, but we can't even put together a decent set of exhibits to show how they lived. More
